abstract: Digital financial tools can greatly improve lives in poor countries, but it is especially crucial to put them into the hands of women, whose role in economic growth is often ignored.
snippet: Digital financial tools can greatly improve lives in poor countries, but it is especially crucial to put them into the hands of women, whose role in economic growth is often ignored.
lead_paragraph: Here is what life is like for a woman with no bank account in a developing country. She keeps her savings hidden — in pots, under mattresses, in fields. She constantly worries about thieves. She may even worry about her husband taking cash she has budgeted for their children’s needs. Sending money to a family member in another village is risky and can take days. Obtaining a loan in an emergency is often impossible.

abstract: Starting Monday a group of lawyers and advocates connected to Adnan Syed, the subject of the podcast “Serial,” will debut another podcast, “Undisclosed: The State v. Adnan Syed.”
snippet: Starting Monday a group of lawyers and advocates connected to Adnan Syed, the subject of the podcast “Serial,” will debut another podcast, “Undisclosed: The State v. Adnan Syed.”
lead_paragraph: The story behind the hit podcast “Serial” is not over. The podcast focused on the 1999 death of Hae Min Lee, a Maryland teenager, and the subsequent conviction of her former boyfriend, Adnan Syed, who is serving a life sentence for murder. It became the fastest podcast to reach five million downloads, according to Apple. Starting Monday a group of lawyers and advocates connected to Mr. Syed will debut another podcast, “Undisclosed: The State v. Adnan Syed,” which will “examine and explore the case in greater detail, from an investigatory perspective instead of a narrative one,” according to a statement. “Undisclosed” is being presented by Rabia Chaudry, a lawyer who has been a longtime advocate of Mr. Syed — as “Serial” fans know, she was the one who suggested that Sarah Koenig, the host of “Serial” and a longtime producer for “This American Life,” look into the case — along with two other lawyers, Susan Simpson and Colin Miller. None of them represent Mr. Syed but each has been investigating the case, Ms. Chaudry said in an interview Tuesday. New episodes of “Undisclosed” are to be released every two weeks. The podcast is sponsored by the Adnan Syed Legal Trust, which, according to a page on the crowdfunding site LaunchGood, is dedicated to Mr. Syed’s defense and has raised $93,000. In November the producers of “Serial” said that a second season was coming. In February a Maryland court agreed to hear an appeal from Mr. Syed, who has said that he is not guilty of Ms. Lee’s murder and that he received ineffective legal counsel at trial.

headline.main: Another ‘Serial’ Chapter, From Group of Lawyers
headline.print_headline: Another ‘Serial’ Chapter, From Group of Lawyers

abstract: The Obama administration said it would review claims that Emirates, Etihad Airways and Qatar Airways received large subsidies from their governments that distorted the global aviation market.
snippet: The Obama administration said it would review claims that Emirates, Etihad Airways and Qatar Airways received large subsidies from their governments that distorted the global aviation market.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said on Friday that it would review claims that Emirates, Etihad Airways and Qatar Airways received large subsidies from their governments that distorted the global aviation market. The top three United States airlines — Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and American Airlines — have asserted recently that their Gulf-based rivals had received more than $42 billion in state aid. They claim the subsidies allowed the Gulf carriers to compete unfairly by buying newer planes and offering better service and amenities. The United States carriers asked the government to freeze any new flights from the United Arab Emirates and Qatar, where the airlines are based, and review open-skies agreements that the United States had signed with the two countries. The Commerce, State and Transportation Departments said in a statement that they took the allegations seriously and would seek public comments.

headline.main: U.S. to Review Complaint About Gulf Air Carriers

lead_paragraph: Without saying a word, a man walks on stage carrying a case full of small plungers. Each time he reaches in the case to take some plungers out, he tries to array them in order on a table in front of him, but he always has one left over. lead_paragraph: I once served on a committee led by a powerful woman. She had strong views, but what I remember most is that whenever I spoke, she nodded her head vigorously and affirmatively. abstract: Alli Webb, the chain’s founder, has elevated the modern blowout into a multimillion-dollar empire and the largest blow-dry chain in the United States.
snippet: Alli Webb, the chain’s founder, has elevated the modern blowout into a multimillion-dollar empire and the largest blow-dry chain in the United States.
lead_paragraph: About 18 people gathered in a semicircle inside Drybar’s new location in the meatpacking district of Manhattan. It was mid-December, and in the previous weeks they had been trained in the fine art of giving the greatest possible blow-dry. They knew how to create the beachy rumpled look of the Mai Tai blowout and the sharp, pointy, uptightness of the Straight Up; they knew how to make you look like an extra from “Steel Magnolias” with the Southern Comfort. They could twist your hair into an Uptini, if that was your need on a particular day. They knew how to turn around the salon chair with a flourish so that the customer, who up to this point had been too mesmerized by watching “The Devil Wears Prada” on a big-screen TV to notice what was being done, could see her hair, shiny and smooth, in the mirror on the wall behind her. As Drybar’s founder, Alli Webb, sitting atop the bar to greet these new employees, likes to say: “We’re not selling blowouts. We’re selling happiness and confidence.”

headline.main: With Drybar, a Curly-Haired Girl Wages a Global War on Frizz
headline.print_headline: A Curly-Haired Girl’s Global War on Frizz

lead_paragraph: IT may sound as if I’m exaggerating when I say that a high-tech, heated, warm-water-spraying bidet toilet seat ruined me for regular toilets, but I’m not. I don’t know how you guys do it. I look at your normal toilets, the ones with seats that are as cold as ice, the ones that don’t spray and buff your nethers with a soothing shower of cleansing H2O, and I shake my head. I look at your dry-wiping ways, and I wonder how your mom raised you. Don’t you want to be clean? Don’t you ever feel ... not so fresh?

snippet: Companies are developing ways to make night driving safer. By combining LED lights with cameras, headlamps can alter their light patterns to fit road conditions.
lead_paragraph: AUTOMOTIVE lighting is undergoing a quiet revolution, leading to new vehicle designs and providing enhanced nighttime safety. But while many of the innovations have become common in Europe and Asia, they have been slower to arrive in the United States.

headline.main: With LED Lights, Automakers Reveal All the Road We Cannot See
headline.print_headline: With LED Lights, Automakers Reveal All the Road We Cannot See

abstract: The company has been methodically upgrading and expanding its manufacturing plants in the United States and elsewhere since its bankruptcy in 2009.
snippet: The company has been methodically upgrading and expanding its manufacturing plants in the United States and elsewhere since its bankruptcy in 2009.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors said Thursday that it would invest $5.4 billion in its American factories over the next three years as part of a broader effort to modernize production facilities and secure jobs.

headline.main: G.M. to Invest $5.4 Billion to Modernize Factories
headline.print_headline: G.M. to Invest $5.4 Billion to Modernize Factories, Including Three in Michigan

snippet: First-quarter earnings were reported a week after Comcast abandoned its planned takeover of Time Warner Cable
lead_paragraph: Time Warner Cable executives provided few clues on Thursday about whether the company would partake in a new round of deal activity, as it missed expectations for first-quarter profit but reported its strongest subscriber growth in years.

headline.print_headline: Results at Time Warner Cable Fall Short of Predictions

abstract: Both companies reported huge drops in profit: a 46 percent decline at Exxon and a 56 percent drop at Shell.
snippet: Both companies reported huge drops in profit: a 46 percent decline at Exxon and a 56 percent drop at Shell.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell on Thursday reported sharply lower quarterly earnings, as improved profits from marketing and refining were offset by the impact of the plunge in oil prices since last summer.

headline.main: Profits at Exxon and Shell Slide, Echoing Oil Prices’ Plunge
headline.print_headline: Sharply Lower Exxon Mobil and Shell Earnings Reflect Oil Prices’ Plunge

lead_paragraph: Last June, in the basement of the Microsoft visitor center in Redmond, Wash., Todd Holmdahl, a Microsoft hardware guru, and others nervously walked Satya Nadella, the new chief executive, through a demonstration of a secret project.

abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration said operators of the Dreamliner jet were to shut down power periodically after a software problem was found.
snippet: The Federal Aviation Administration said operators of the Dreamliner jet were to shut down power periodically after a software problem was found.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators will order operators of Boeing 787 Dreamliners to shut down the plane’s electrical power periodically after Boeing discovered a software error that could result in a total loss of power.

headline.main: F.A.A. Orders Fix for Possible Power Loss in Boeing 787
headline.print_headline: Regulators Order Power Fix for Boeing 787

abstract: Mr. Greenberg, soon to turn 90, is scheduled to take the witness stand in July after years of discovery and maneuvers in the fraud case that accuses him of accounting fraud.
snippet: Mr. Greenberg, soon to turn 90, is scheduled to take the witness stand in July after years of discovery and maneuvers in the fraud case that accuses him of accounting fraud.
lead_paragraph: To his accusers, Maurice R. Greenberg, also known as Hank, is just one in a line of disgraced chief executives from the mid-2000s who resorted to accounting fraud to pad their lavish bonuses. But even they have to admit one thing: The man has stamina.

headline.main: Hank Greenberg Still in the Ring at 90, Battling A.I.G. Charges
headline.print_headline: Still in the Ring at 90, Battling for A.I.G.

abstract: Sales of Harvoni and an earlier hepatitis C drug, Sovaldi, far exceeded Wall Street expectations and made the company one of the top earners in pharmaceuticals.
snippet: Sales of Harvoni and an earlier hepatitis C drug, Sovaldi, far exceeded Wall Street expectations and made the company one of the top earners in pharmaceuticals.
lead_paragraph: Sales of Gilead Sciences’ drugs to treat hepatitis C reached $4.55 billion in the first quarter, far exceeding already lofty Wall Street expectations but likely to focus attention once again on the overall costs to the health care system of the medicines.

headline.main: Gilead Hepatitis Drugs Brought In $4.55 Billion in First Quarter
headline.print_headline: Gilead Earnings Surge as Sales of Hepatitis Drugs Double, Exceeding Forecasts
